cc:Work.dc:title: Meno 82b-85d: Socrates and the Slave
cc:Work.dc:description: A visual representation of Socrates' interrogation of the slave in Plato's Meno.

svg.title: Meno 82b-85d: Socrates and the Slave
svg.desc: "Meno 82b-85d: Socrates and the Slave" is a visual companion to part of Plato's dialogue "Meno" which inquires as to whether virtue can be taught. In particular, it is a visual companion to the part of the dialogue in which Plato has Socrates question a slave boy so as to show the Theory of Recollection at work.

text.tspan: line 1
line 2
line 3
line 4
Meno 82b - 85d: Socrates and the Slave
Socrates: Pay attention now to the questions which I ask him, and observe
whether he is learning from me or only recollecting.
Meno: I will pay attention.
Socrates: Tell me now, boy, do you know that a figure like this is a square?
Slave: I do.
Socrates: And you know that a square figure has these four lines equal?
Slave: Certainly.
Socrates: And these lines which I have drawn through the middle of
the square are also equal?
Slave: Yes.
Socrates: And a square may be of any size?
Slave: Certainly.
Socrates: And if one side of the figure is two feet long, and the other side
two feet long, how much is the whole? Let me explain: if in one direction
the length is two feet, and in the other direction one foot, the whole is two
feet taken once?
Slave: Yes.
Socrates: But since this side is also two feet long, there are twice two feet?
Slave: There are.
Socrates: Then the square is twice two feet?
Slave: Yes.
Socrates: And how many are twice two feet? Count and tell me.
Slave: Four, Socrates.
Socrates: And might there not be another square twice as large as this,
which also has four lines equal?
Slave: Yes.
Socrates: And how many feet will that be?
Slave: Eight feet.
Socrates: And now try and tell me the length of the line which forms the side
of that double square. This is two feet -- what will that be?
Slave: Clearly, Socrates, it will be double.
Socrates: Have you noticed, Meno, that I am not teaching the boy anything but am only
asking him questions. And now he thinks that he knows the length of line needed in
order to produce a figure of eight feet. Doesn't he think this?
Meno: Yes.
Socrates: And does he really know?
Meno: Certainly not.
Socrates: He is only guessing that the line is double because the square is double.
Meno: True.
Socrates: Watch him while he recollects the steps in regular order. Tell me, boy,
do you say that a double space comes from a double line? Remember that I am
not speaking of a figure long on one side and short on the other, but of a figure
equals every way, and twice the size of this -- that is to say, of eight feet. And I
want to know whether you still say that a double square comes from double line?
Slave: Yes.
Socrates: But does not this line become doubled if we add another such line here?
line 1
line 2
line 3
line 4
Slave: Certainly.
Socrates: And four such lines will make a figure containing eight feet?
Slave: Yes.
Socrates: Let us describe such a figure. Would you not say that this
is the figure of eight feet?
Slave: Yes.
Socrates: And are there not these four divisions in the figure, each
of which is equal to the figure of four feet?
Slave: True.
Socrates: And is not that four times four?
Slave: Certainly.
Socrates: And four times is not double?
Slave: No, indeed.
Socrates: But how much?
Slave: Four times as much.
Socrates: Therefore the double line, boy, has given a figure,
not twice, but four times as much.
Slave: True.
Socrates: Four times four are sixteen -- are they not?
Slave: Yes.
Socrates: What line would give you a figure of eight feet, as
this gives one of sixteen feet? Do you see?
Slave: Yes.
Socrates: And the figure of four feet is made from this half line?
Slave: Yes.
Socrates: Good, and is not a figure of eight feet twice the size of
this, and half the size of the other?
Socrates: Such a figure, then, will be made out of a line greater
than this one, and less than that one?
Slave: Yes.
Socrates: Very good, I like to hear you say what you think. And
now tell me, is not this a line of two feet and that of four?
Slave: Yes, I think so.
Slave: Yes.
Socrates: Then the line which forms the side of a figure of eight feet
ought to be more than this line of two feet, and less than the other of
four feet?
Slave: It ought.
Socrates: Try and see if you can tell me how much it will be.
Slave: Three feet.
Socrates: Then if we add a half to this line of two, that will be the line
of three. Here are two and there is one. And on the other side, here are
two also and there is one. And that makes the figure of which you speak?
Slave: Yes.
Socrates: But if there are three feet this way and three feet that way, the
whole space will be three times three feet?
Slave: That is evident.
Socrates: And how much are three times three feet?
Slave: Nine.
Socrates: And how much is the double of four?
Slave: Eight.
Socrates: Then the figure of eight is not made out of a side of three?
Slave: No.
Socrates: But from what line? Tell me exactly, and if you would
rather not reckon, try and show me the line.
Slave: By Zeus, Socrates, I do not know.
Socrates: Do you see, Meno, what advances he has made in his
power of recollection? He did not know at first, and he does not
know now, what is the side of a figure of eight feet. But then he
thought that he knew, and answered confidently as if he knew,
and had no difficulty. Now he has a difficulty, and neither knows
nor thinks that he knows.
Meno: True.
Socrates: Is he not better off in knowing his ignorance?
Meno: I think that he is.
Socrates: If we have perplexed him, and made him numb
as the torpedo fish does, have we done him any harm?
Meno: I think not.
Socrates: We have certainly, it would seem, assisted him in
some degree to the discovery of the truth. And now he will wish
to remedy his ignorance, whereas before he would have been ready
to tell all the world again and again that the double space should
have a double side.
Meno: True.
Socrates: But do you suppose that he would ever have inquired
into or learned what he thought that he knew, though he was really
ignorant of it, until he had fallen into perplexity under the idea that
he did not know, and had desired to know?
Meno: I think not, Socrates.
Socrates: Then he was the better for the torpedo's touch?
Meno: I think so.
Socrates: Pay attention now to what happens. I shall only ask him,
and not teach him, and he shall share the inquiry with me. And do
watch and see if you find me telling or explaining anything to
him, instead of eliciting his opinion. Tell me, boy, is not this a
square of four feet which I have drawn?
Slave: Yes.
Socrates: And now I add another square equal to the former one?
Slave: Yes.
Socrates: And a third, which is equal to either of them?
Slave: Yes.
Socrates: Suppose that we fill up the vacant corner?
Slave: Very good.
Socrates: Here, then, there are four equal spaces?
Slave: Yes.
Socrates: And how many times larger is this space than this other?
Slave: Four times.
Socrates: But it ought to have been twice only, as you will remember.
Slave: True.
Socrates: And does not this line, reaching from corner to corner,
bisect each of these spaces?
Slave: Yes.
Socrates: And are there not here four equal lines which contain
this space?
Slave: There are.
Socrates: Look and see how much this space is.
Slave: I do not understand.
Socrates: Has not each interior line cut off half of the four spaces?
Slave: Yes.
Socrates: And how many spaces are there in this section?
Slave: Four.
Socrates: And how many in this?
Slave: Two.
Socrates: And four is how many times two?
Slave: Twice.
Socrates: And this space is of how many feet?
Slave: Of eight feet.
Socrates: And from what line do you get this figure?
Slave: From this.
Socrates: That is, from the line which extends from corner to
corner of the figure of four feet?
Slave: Yes.
Socrates: And that is the line which the learned call the diagonal.
And if this is the proper name, then you, Meno's slave, are prepared
to affirm that the double space is the square of the diagonal?
Slave: Certainly, Socrates.
Socrates: What do you say of him, Meno? Were not all these answers
given out of his own head?
Meno: Yes, they were all his own.
Socrates: And yet, as we were just now saying, he did not know?
Meno: True.
Socrates: But still he had in him those opinions of his -- had he not?
Meno: Yes.
Socrates: Then he who does not know may still have true opinions of
that which he does not know?
Meno: So it seems.
Socrates: And at present these opinions have just been stirred up in him,
as in a dream. But if he were frequently asked the same questions in
various ways, in the end he would know as well as anyone?
Meno: I dare say.
Socrates: He will recover this knowledge for himself, without anyone
teaching him, if only he is asked questions?
Meno: Yes.
Socrates: And this spontaneous recovery of knowledge in him is
recollection?
Meno: True.
